text.headline: Arts Ecosystem Timeline
text.text:
Documenting the evolution of the Seattle region's arts ecosystem since the 1962 World's Fair.

Timeline entries and related research are added each year as completed by graduate students.

text.headline: Seattle World's Fair
text.text:
The Century 21 Exposition, popularly known as the Seattle World's Fair, included numerous arts events and exhibitions of international stature. It was held April 21 to October 21, 1962, and nearly 10 million people attended.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit, Governmental
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Multidisciplinary
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Festival/Event, Presenter, Community Development

text.headline: Seattle Center Opera House
text.text:
The grand opening of the Seattle Center Opera House occurred in conjunction with the opening of the Seattle World's Fair in 1962. Van Cliburn performed Rachimanioff’s Piano Concerto No. 3 and Igor Stravinsky conducted the Seattle Symphony in a performance of his Firebird Suite. In 2003 the building was significantly refurbished and reopened as Marion Oliver McCaw Hall.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit, Governmental
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Music, Dance, Theatre
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter, Venue/Facility

text.headline: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture
text.text:
The roots of the Burke Museum date back to 1885, when the Young Naturalists' Society raised money to start a museum to house their growing natural history collection. Soon after, it moved to the campus of the University of Washington and in 1899 was designated as the Washington State Museum. It was named after Judge Thomas Burke in recognition of a bequest in 1962. Over time, the museum continued to grow its programs and collection of fossils, specimens, art and artifacts from the Pacific Northwest and around the Pacific Rim, necessitating a larger facility. Construction on the “New Burke” began in 2016 and was largely guided by the leadership of long time Executive Director, Julie Stein. The New Burke opened to the public in October of 2019.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Crafts, Visual Arts, Folk/traditional/heritage Arts, Other
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Other

text.headline: Jack Straw Cultural Center
text.text:
The non-profit multidisciplinary audio arts center Jack Straw opened in 1962. It relocated to the University District in 1989. They provide a variety of resources for community artists, including Jack Straw Productions, studio and recording services, educational programs, residency programs, an artist support program, the New Media Gallery, and Writer's Program Residency. KRAB Radio Station was operated by the Jack Straw Foundation from 1964 until its demise in 1984.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Multidisciplinary Arts, Media Arts, New Media, Other: Audio
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Service(s) for Artists, Arts Education: Adults, Arts Education: Youth and Children

text.headline: KRAB-FM
text.text:
Lorenzo Milam founded the subscriber-based, freeform community radio station KRAB 107.7 FM Seattle in 1962, and it was run under the Jack Straw Memorial Foundation from 1964 until going off-air for good in 1984. It was only the fourth commercial-free, listener-supported radio station in the United States and became known for an exceptionally wide variety of programming and occasional troubles with the FCC. The Jack Straw Memorial Foundation later established a community radio station in Snohomish County in 1991, KSER-FM. The Foundation also continues to exist, and still operates the Jack Straw Cultural Center as of 2022.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Music, Other: Radio
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Broadcast Media

text.headline: Seattle Center
text.text:
The World's Fair venue transitioned to a City of Seattle-managed community arts and culture campus in 1963. Many of the current structures on the campus still date back to the World's Fair, while more than $860 million has been invested into Seattle Center since 1990. Seattle Center is known for being the home to large scale events and festivals such as Bumbershoot, Northwest Folklife, and the Festal cultural festivals. The campus is also the location of multiple arts venues and organizations, including (as of 2021) the Cornish Playhouse, KEXP, Seattle Opera, Pacific Northwest Ballet, Seattle Children's Theatre, Seattle Repertory Theatre, The Vera Project, Chihuly Garden and Glass, and the Museum of Pop Culture (MoPOP).

  • Primary Form of Entity: Governmental
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Multidisciplinary

text.headline: Cinerama/SIFF Cinema Downtown
text.text:
The Seattle Cinerama Theater first opened in 1963. Over the next 50 years, the once state-of-the-art projection system, capable of screening three-strip films on its 97-foot curved screen, would become one of only two left in the world. Through the 1980s and 90s, the single-screen theater faced declining business, fell into disrepair, and was in danger of being demolished. Paul G. Allen purchased the theater in 1998 and set about reviving it. With a series of renovations and management under Paul G. Allen's Vulcan Real Estate, the Cinerama once again became a landmark destination for blockbuster and independent movies, as well as a variety of film festivals and other events, amplified by chocolate popcorn, memorabilia from the Allen Family Collection on display, and a mural on the external wall facing Fourth Avenue.

After Allen's death in February 2020, Vulcan announced the closure of the venue again for renovations, saying it would reopen later the same year. Vulcan proceeded to sunset their entire Arts + Entertainment division by end of 2020, and the Cinerama closure extended indefinitely. In May 2023, the Seattle International Film Festival (SIFF) acquired and took over operations of Cinerama, under the name SIFF Cinema Downtown, opening on December 14, 2023. The venue, under SIFF, continues to feature blockbuster studio films and first-run arthouse cinema, as well as specialty festivals and events, with reserved seating and locally sourced concessions including their famous chocolate popcorn.

  • Primary Form of Entity: for profit, nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Media Arts, Other: Film
  • Primary Areas of Activity: presenter/distributor, venue/facility

text.headline: Seattle Opera
text.text:
The Seattle Opera was founded in 1963. Its founding General Director, Glynn Ross, opened the company with performances of Puccini's Tosca. His twenty-year tenure was followed by thirty years of leadership by Speight Jenkins. Over the decades, the Seattle Opera has been based at Seattle Center, moving into the extensively renovated Marion Oliver McCaw Hall in 2003.

The Seattle Opera presents high quality operas, ranging from traditional productions to new commissions with nationally and internationally recognized artists. For a number of years they produced internationally acclaimed productions of Wagner's Der Ring des Nibelungen. With a long history of training young singers, the Seattle Opera's youth programs regularly visit more than 75 schools across the state. The Seattle Opera's Young Artists Program ran from 1998 to 2013, and they hosted the International Wagner Competition in 2006, 2008, and 2014.

  • Primary Form of Entity: for profit, nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Multidisciplinary, Music, Theatre
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter/Distributor

text.headline: Zoë Dusanne Gallery
text.text:
Zoë Dusanne's Gallery was known as Seattle's first professional modern art gallery. Founded in 1950, the Gallery operated out of Dusanne's home overlooking Lake Union. In 1958, the house, and subsequently the Gallery, were demolished in order to build the Seattle Freeway. Dusanne reopened the gallery in 1959 but it closed permanently in 1964 because of the forced move.

Zoë Dusanne supported Northwest artists who specialized in painting. Her home became a meeting space for Seattle's art community, and she strove to educate the public about modern art and local painters. She had a strong working relationship with Dr. Richard E. Fuller of the Seattle Art Museum, and the Henry Gallery.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Facility/Venue, Service(s) for Artists, Presenter/Distributor

text.headline: Chihuly Studio
text.text:
Dale Chihuly is noted for his glass art that has been displayed in over 200 museums worldwide. Chihuly Studio is based out of the Pacific Northwest and located in The Boathouse on Lake Union in Seattle. Chihuly's work involves a communal, team-based approach to glassblowing that has had an enduring impact on the field. In 1971, with the patronage of John and Anne Gould Hauberg, he and several fellow artists established the Pilchuck Glass School in Washington State, the leading institution of its kind. Chihuly's hometown of Tacoma is the site of a 500-foot pedestrian walkway, Bridge of Glass, which features his work. In 2013 he opened Chihuly Garden and Glass, a long-term exhibit at the foot of the Space Needle in Seattle Center.

text.headline: A Contemporary Theatre (ACT)
text.text:
ACT was founded in 1965 by Gregory Falls, head of the University of Washington Drama department. Based in lower Queen Anne until 1996, ACT then moved to the historic Eagles Auditorium building in downtown Seattle, which was renamed Kreielsheimer Place after major contributions from the Kreielsheimer Foundation. ACT's programming primarily focuses on new works and contemporary theatre.

  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter, Producer, Facility/Venue

text.text:

text.headline: Central Area Motivation Program (CAMP)
text.text:
Central Area Motivation Program (CAMP) was founded in 1964 as part of the first generation of community-inspired organizations funded by the Economic Opportunity Act. CAMP was centered on supporting the Black communities of Seattle and flourished during the civil rights movement with programming that centered around the creative arts and community beautification. CAMP coupled these with practical assistance such as childcare facilities, and job placement to assist residents in finding a better quality of life. CAMP was also the original home to Black/Arts West, Seattle's first Black theater. Over the years, CAMP has expanded its range of programming into equity-focused services such as energy assistance, a food bank, housing assistance, and education in personal finance. In 2018, CAMP changed its name to Byrd Barr Place in honor of local civil rights leader Roberta Byrd Barr.

  • Primary Form of Entity: For Profit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Multidisciplinary Arts, Interdisciplinary Arts
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Venue/Facility, Arts Education: Children and Youth, Presenter/Distributor, Arts in Social Service/Social Justice, Arts in Community Development

text.headline: Pacific Northwest Black Community Festival
text.text:
Umoja Fest/African Heritage Festival and Parade has been a celebration of ethnic diversity showcasing local, national and international artists in Seattle since the 1940s. Dedicated to highlighting the countless contributions of African Americans, Umoja Fest originally developed from the International Festival of the 1940s and has seen many transformations over the decades. In 1952, it became known as the East Madison/East Union Mardi Gras Festival. The name changed to the Pacific Northwest Black Community Festival in the 1960s, and since 1997, it has been known as Umoja Fest/African Heritage Festival and Parade.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Music, Dance, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts, Multidisciplinary
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Arts Education: Children and Youth, Arts Education: Adults, Arts in Social Service/Social Justice, Arts in Community Development, Festival/Event.

text.headline: Washington State Arts Alliance
text.text:
Founded in 1967, Washington State Arts Alliance was a statewide arts advocacy organization to promote public funding, legislation, and policy favorable to the arts. WSAA merged with Cultural Access Washington in early 2019 to form the cultural access organization Inspire Washington.
Inspire Washington works with member organizations, or Cultural Partners, to advocate for increased access to arts, heritage, and science activities and experiences for the people of all communities across the state of Washington.

  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Multidisciplinary
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Policy/Advocacy, Services to Arts Organizations

text.headline: Wing Luke Museum
text.text:
Wing Luke Museum was founded in 1967 in the Chinatown International District to focus on the history and culture of Asian Pacific Americans, becoming the only pan-Asian Pacific American community -based museum in the United States. The WING rehabilitated the historic East Kong Yick Building as its expanded home in 2008.

text.headline: Black Arts/West
text.text:
Black Arts/West is recognized as Seattle's first Black theater with three core programs: theater, dance, and an art gallery. Started in 1969 by Douglas Q. Barnett, Black Arts/West developed as a division of the Central Area Motivation Program (CAMP) and was supported by the Seattle Model Cities program. It closed in 1980 having gained national recognition for excellence in producing and presenting Black theater. Black Arts/West served as the foundation for the creation of Nu Black Arts West Theatre, under the direction of Kibibi Monié.

  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre, Dance, Visual Arts, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts

text.headline: Seward Park Clay Studio
text.text:
Seward Park Clay Studio was founded in 1969 and has operated as a non-profit educational ceramics institution since 1986. It occupies the historic 1927 Seward Park Bathhouse under agreement with City of Seattle's Department of Parks and Recreation, providing education and development of the ceramicist community in the greater Seattle area.

text.headline: The Bathhouse Theater
text.text:
Built in 1927 as a place for bathers on the shore of popular Green Lake, The Bathhouse was converted by the City of Seattle into a small theater in 1969-1970. The Bathhouse Theater's 165-seat capacity has been home to varied theater performances, first as a Seattle Parks and Recreation program and then as the home of Seattle Public Theater starting in 2000.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Governmental, Nonprofit

  • Primary Areas of Activity: Producer, Presenter, Venue/Facility

text.headline: Black Heritage Society of Washington State
text.text:
Founded in 1970, the Black Heritage Society of Washington is a community led organization that preserves the history and art of Black Washingtonians through collecting and archiving historical documents and photos, as well as conducting fundraising and educational initiatives. Housed at the University of Washington's Special Collections, the Black Heritage Society has gathered an array of oral histories, information about the historical contributions of Black Washingtonians, and documentation of the history of Black culture and arts in Washington. The Black Heritage Society also frequently collaborates with the Museum of History and Industry (MOHAI) on related exhibits.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter/distributor, Other: archive

text.headline: United Indians of all Tribes Foundation
text.text:
Bernie Whitebear (1937-2000) was a leader in the establishment of the United Indians of All Tribes Foundation (UIAT) which has served urban Natives in Western Washington since 1970. The organization provides social services and acts as a community and cultural hub, and advocacy group. The UIAT is responsible for establishing the Daybreak Star Cultural Center, which opened in 1977 in Seattle's 534-acre Discovery Park and includes an art gallery and gift shop and the ongoing Emerging Native Artists Cohort program.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit

text.headline: Paramount Theater
text.text:
Originally built in 1928, the Paramount Theater has had a series of owners. After being closed for a period of time in the 1960s, it reopened as “Paramount Northwest” in 1971 and operated primarily as a music venue for rock bands and jazz and soul musicians. The Paramount was considered the only major venue for Black artists and musicians in Seattle and from roughly the 1960s through the 1980s was the main venue for performances by artists like Sly and the Family Stone, Bob Marley, Parliament Funkadelic and more. The apartments upstairs had been converted to house traveling musicians early in the Paramount's history, but continued to house a small group of artists and other residents through at least the mid-1990s. The Seattle Theater Group (STG) gained sole ownership of the Paramount Theater in 1999 and continues to operate it today with a range of programming, including touring Broadway shows, dance, jazz, live concerts, comedy shows, and more.

  • Primary Form of Entity: For Profit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre, Music, Dance
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Venue/Facility

text.headline: Northwest Folklife Festival
text.text:
Northwest Folklife Festival features a broad range of cultural expression and traditions practiced in the Northwest. It has been held annually on Memorial Day weekend throughout Seattle Center since 1972. This popular event attracts 100,000 to 250,000 audience members and thousands of performers each year. Folklife also offers year-round programming for youth and families. Northwest Folklife Festival has always been a free event dedicated to making traditional arts and culture accessible to the public without barriers. Starting in 1998, Folklife began requesting a donation from audience members at the gate to help meet fundraising goals necessary for continuing the annual festival.

text.headline: El Centro de la Raza
text.text:
El Centro de la Raza was founded in October 1972 as the result of a 75-day peaceful occupation of the abandoned Beacon Hill School. The occupation led to negotiations with the Mayor's office and resulted in the City agreeing to sublease the building to El Centro de la Raza for $1 a year. El Centro de la Raza was initially inspired by the desire and need for a hub for the Latino community in Seattle but evolved to become a multi-cultural organization. Founder Roberto Maestas served as the Executive Director until 2009. El Centro de la Raza provides many social and other services to people in need and uses the arts as a means of social change and activism. Arts-related programming includes an art and mural gallery and features traditional art and artists in larger events. In 1997, the school district raised the rent to the market rate of $12,000/month, but $1 million in grants from the City of Seattle and Washington state helped El Centro de la Raza purchase the building from the school district.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts

text.headline: Bailadores de Bronce
text.text:
Bailadores de Bronce is a Ballet Folklorico company that was founded in 1972 at the University of Washington by a group of students led by Josefina Jaramillo Alvarez. Inspired by the Civil Rights and Chicano movements, the students recognized the lack of a Mexican dance group at the university and wanted to share their pride in their Chicano heritage through music and dance. The group became a nonprofit organization around 2010. Bailadores de Bronce has been led by several long-term directors; most recently, Adrian Olivas became the Executive and Artistic Director in 2012.

text.headline: Ethnic Cultural Center & Theatre (ECC)
text.text:
The Ethnic Cultural Center & Theatre (ECC) at the University of Washington opened its doors in 1972 as a performance venue with the goal of supporting greater diversity in programming within the institution. A direct response to student demands, the ECC has worked with BIPOC students and faculty, as well as community organizations for more than 40 years to encourage cross-cultural exchange and learning. The ECC also housed the Group Theatre Company from 1978 to 1992, when the company moved to the Center House Theatre. In 2013, the ECC was renovated and renamed the Samuel E. Kelly Ethnic Cultural Center in honor of the late leader of minority affairs at the UW. Today it is recognized as the largest and longest standing cultural center on a college campus within the United States.

text.headline: Northwest Asian American Theatre (NWAAT)
text.text:
Originally founded by a group of Asian American students in 1972 on the University of Washington campus at the school's Ethnic Cultural Center Northwest Asian American Theatre became a flagship Asian American theatre company in the Pacific Northwest and the first of its kind in the region. In 1987, after the ensemble students graduated from the University of Washington, NWAAT moved theater operations into an automobile repair shop and converted this garage space into the Theatre Off Jackson, a 140-seat venue that still provides performance space to a rotating number of groups. Bea Kiyohara served as Artistic Director of NWAAT for most of the company's existence, from 1978 until 1993. NWAAT was celebrated for producing work that connected with a diverse audience and for supporting local APA actors, directors, and playwrights who went on to great success after their time at NWAAT. The Northwest Asian American Theatre closed its doors in 2004.

  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre, Folk/Traditional/Heritage arts, Multidisciplinary Arts

These ordinances were among the first nationally, and the programs have been emulated by cities and counties across the nation.

text.text:
Safeco, a Seattle-based insurance company, built a major collection of Pacific Northwest art starting in 1973 to enhance their workplace while giving employees insight into Northwest art; to support local artists; and to support local galleries by buying works featured there. The collection was dispersed with over 840 works donated to the Washington Arts Consortium in 2010 after the company became part of Liberty Mutual.

text.text:
Linda Farris first operated a gallery in Bellevue before establishing her groundbreaking avant-garde gallery in Pioneer Square in 1972, representing a group of young University of Washington MFA graduates and noted national contemporary artists. The gallery is credited with significantly contributing to the careers of many Seattle artists and the evolution of a nationally-noted art scene in Seattle before closing in 1995.

text.headline: Bumbershoot Festival
text.text:
The first event to make use of the entire Seattle Center campus after the World's Fair was Festival '71, also known as the Mayor's Arts Festival, which became the annual Bumbershoot festival in 1973, produced by One Reel since 1980. In 1973 the annual festival became known as Bumbershoot and in 1976 it was moved to Labor Day weekend. Bumbershoot has been produced by One Reel since 1980, which is also the first year that admission was charged for the festival. Over the years, Bumbershoot has hosted major local, national and international music acts. However, after conflict over ticketing prices and fluctuating audiences, Bumbershoot partnered with concert company AEG from 2015 to 2019 to help them pay existing debts and to manage the booking of their music acts. As of 2021, Bumbershoot has partnered with Seattle Center to form the Bumbershoot Exploratory Committee in order to plan for a sustainable future for the event.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Governmental

text.headline: Total Experience Gospel Choir
text.text:
Seattle's longest lasting and most prominent community gospel choir, Total Experience was founded in 1973 by Pastor Patrinell Staten Wright. It was originally established for African American children and teens after a comparable program at Franklin High School was defunded. Adults began participating in the 1990s, and as the ethnic makeup of the Central District changed, so did the choir. They performed in 28 states and 22 countries over the course of 45 years, before their last performance in October 2018. In 2019, the inspirational story of Reverend Wright and Total Experience was immortalized in the film Patrinell: The Total Experience.

  • Primary Form of Entity: For Profit

text.headline: and/or
text.text:
and/or was founded in 1974 by Anne Focke and a collective group of artists in Seattle's Capitol Hill neighborhood. It was the first alternative art space in the Northwest for performances, exhibitions, and other experimental art forms that could not be seen otherwise, and was nationally recognized as an influential arts entity. In 1984 and/or intentionally disbanded, resulting in offshoots like CoCA, Artist Trust, Artech, and 911 Media Arts taking on independent status.

text.headline: Meany Center for the Performing Arts
text.text:
The Meany Center for the Performing Arts at the University of Washington is a community resource and performance hall. Located on the University of Washington Campus, the Meany Center was built in 1974, replacing the “Old Meany Hall” that had stood since 1909. The Meany has two theaters and hosts a highly regarded annual season of international performances as well as student performances from the University of Washington's School of Drama, School of Music, Dance Program, and the Center for Digital Arts & Experimental Media.

text.headline: Seattle Children's Theater
text.text:
The Seattle Children's Theatre (SCT) brings professional theater and theater education to children and youth in the greater Puget Sound region. After starting out at the PONCHO Theatre on the grounds of the Woodland Park Zoo, and being officially founded in 1975, SCT moved in 1993 to its newly built Charlotte Martin Theatre at Seattle Center, under Artistic Director Linda Hartzell. Nationally and internationally recognized for its commitment to new works, SCT's 482-seat and 275-seat theaters are also home to the SCT Drama School.

text.headline: Ewajo Dance Studio
text.text:
Ewajo Dance Studio was opened in 1975 in Wallingford by dance teacher Edna Daigre, who was looking for a home for her dance classes blending conditioning, Afro-Latin and jazz dance. Ewajo, which is named after the Yoruba word for “common dance”, had several locations, but moved to the corner of Madison Street and Martin Luther King Jr. Way in 1989. Ewajo Dance Studio closed in 2007 but Chris Daigre, Edna Daigre's son, is still teaching dance classes in Seattle as of 2021.

text.headline: Seattle International Film Festival
text.text:
The first Seattle International Film Festival was in 1976 and grew to attract almost 150,000 filmgoers annually with features, short films, and documentaries from more than 80 countries and territories worldwide. Year-round programming of the SIFF organization as of 2024 includes screenings, Film Talks and spotlight festivals at the four SIFF Cinema theatres, as well as the annual Seattle International Film Festival, SIFF Education, and SIFFsupports.

During the opening night of 49th Festival in 2023, SIFF's then executive director Tom Mara announced the organization had acquired the Cinerama Theatre from the Paul G. Allen estate. The SIFF Cinerama Downtown opened on December 14, 2023, becoming the fourth theater operated by Seattle International Film Festival, joining the SIFF Cinema Uptown, which was acquired in 2011; and the historic Egyptian Theater in Capitol Hill, now SIFF Cinema Egyptian, which was acquired in 2014.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit

text.headline: Artist-designed Hatchcovers Project
text.text:

text.headline: Seattle Cherry Blossom and Japanese Cultural Festival
text.text:
On May 8, 1976, Japan's former Prime Minister, Takeo Miki gifted 1000 Cherry trees to the City of Seattle as a gesture of friendship which would impact the region for decades. This commemoration of America's bicentennial and the long-standing relationship between Japan and Washington State quickly developed into the annual Seattle Cherry Blossom and Japanese Cultural Festival, which is still active to this day. Yutaka and Tazue Sasaki have been instrumental in the festival since 1979, leading it for many years. The festival has become known as the largest celebration of Japanese music, dance and culture in the Northwest, offering unique opportunities to Japanese and Japanese American artists to present and grow their work in a public setting.

  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts, Multidisciplinary Arts

text.headline: Daybreak Star Indian Cultural Center
text.text:
The Daybreak Star Indian Cultural Center was established by the United Indians of All Tribes (UIAT) Foundation and opened in 1977 in Seattle's Discovery Park following years of Native American activism and non-violent occupation of the land in 1970. It serves as a land base and community center for Indigenous people in the region, and the headquarters for the UIAT, providing education, cultural, and social services, as well as event space for Native American cultural activities. The building also includes permanent works of Native American art and the Sacred Circle Gallery.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Multidisciplinary, Heritage

text.headline: Rosco Louie Gallery
text.text:
Co-founded by local artists Larry Reid and Tracey Rowland, Rosco Louie was located in Pioneer Square and served as an early venue for many underground visual, music and performance artists. Rosco Louie was also a gathering place for Seattle's punk scene and became known for rejecting the highbrow values often associated with art galleries. Rosco Louie closed in 1982, but Reid and Rowland would go on to other roles in the art community. Notably, Reid has played a major role at Fantagraphics Bookstore & Gallery in Georgetown.

text.headline: Group Theatre Company
text.text:
Started in 1978, Seattle Group Theatre Company was one of the first multicultural theater companies in the country and a leader in the movement for multicultural and inclusive casting, under Founding Artistic Director Ruben Sierra. Housed at the University of Washington's Ethnic Cultural Theatre from 1978 to 1992, The Group as it was locally known, moved to the Center House Theatre at Seattle Center in 1993 and resided there until 1998. The Group closed its doors in 1998 having presented the works of many Black, Asian, and Latino playwrights, directors, and actors.

text.text:
On the Boards (OtB) was founded in 1978 to produce and present unique performance projects by leading contemporary artists. It was based in Washington Hall until 1998 when OtB moved into its own venue in lower Queen Anne, where its annual programming includes works by international, national and local artists.

text.headline: Earthworks: Land Reclamation as Sculpture Symposium
text.text:
The King County Arts Commission, one of the first county arts agencies in the country, sponsored a landmark symposium, Earthworks: Land Reclamation as Sculpture, in 1979. The symposium and a related exhibition hosted by the Seattle Art Museum, has been described as a turning point in public art program management, combining artists working with public works departments and civil engineers. The exhibit spent two years touring museums and government facilities around the country. Although none of the designs presented by the artists were ever completed by the site sponsors, the Symposium resulted in two commissions in south King County that continue to be managed for public access by 4Culture. Robert Morris' Untitled Earthwork (Johnson Pit #30), located in the Kent valley, is a pioneering example of an artwork that rehabilitates landscape damaged by industry. It was listed in the Washington Heritage Register in 2021 and is also included on the National Register of Historic Places. Herbert Bayer's landmarked Mill Creek Canyon Earthworks addresses storm water issues by creating a functioning watershed and a popular recreation site in Kent.

text.headline: Black Arts/West
text.text:
Black Arts/West is recognized as Seattle's first Black theater with three core programs: theater, dance, and an art gallery. Started in 1969 by Douglas Q. Barnett, Black Arts/West developed as a division of the Central Area Motivation Program (CAMP) and was supported by the Seattle Model Cities program. It closed in 1980 having gained national recognition for excellence in producing and presenting Black theater. Black Arts/West served as the foundation for the creation of Nu Black Arts West Theatre, under the direction of Kibibi Monié.

text.headline: Bumbershoot Festival
text.text:
The first event to make use of the entire Seattle Center campus after the World's Fair was Festival '71, also known as the Mayor's Arts Festival, which became the annual Bumbershoot festival in 1973, produced by One Reel since 1980. In 1973 the annual festival became known as Bumbershoot and in 1976 it was moved to Labor Day weekend. Bumbershoot has been produced by One Reel since 1980, which is also the first year that admission was charged for the festival. Over the years, Bumbershoot has hosted major local, national and international music acts. However, after conflict over ticketing prices and fluctuating audiences, Bumbershoot partnered with concert company AEG from 2015 to 2019 to help them pay existing debts and to manage the booking of their music acts. As of 2021, Bumbershoot has partnered with Seattle Center to form the Bumbershoot Exploratory Committee in order to plan for a sustainable future for the event.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Governmental; Nonprofit (One Reel)

text.headline: Pioneer Square First Thursday Art Walk
text.text:
A group of Pioneer Square gallery owners collaborated to create the first gallery map and art walk in the country in February 1980, which became the popular First Thursday Art Walk. This event has continued since that time, with Encore Publishing taking on the map and guide in 1986, and then as a project of the Seattle Art Dealers Association (SADA) in 2005.

text.headline: Festival Sundiata
text.text:
Festival Sundiata (Sundiata African American Cultural Association) has presented a Black Arts-centered weekend long festival and served as a community gathering space since 1980. Held at Seattle Center, Festival Sundiata is the largest gathering focused on African American culture, arts, and entertainment in the State of Washington. The festival celebrates the diversity of black arts making and has had performances by legendary acts such as Gil Scott-Heron, Calypso King, James Moody, Mighty Sparrow, Albert King and Hip Hop artist Wale. In addition to musical acts, the festival holds visual arts exhibitions and has also celebrated historical moments such as the release of Nelson Mandela in 1990. Starting with a number of volunteers, the Festival has become a yearlong promotion and production effort with over 150 volunteers and community and corporate sponsors to support live performances, art exhibitions, educational programming, and vendors.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts, Music, Dance, Crafts, Multi and Interdisciplinary Arts, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts

text.headline: Gallery Desta
text.text:
Located in the heart of Seattle's Central District between S. Jackson St. and Martin Luther King Jr. Way S., Gallery Desta provided the Seattle Black community with curated exhibitions focused on the Black experience. Owned and operated by Doreen Mitchum the gallery presented both local and internationally recognized artists including Al Doggett, George Cook, and Keith Haynes during the gallery's brief tenure from the beginning of 1980 through the end of that same year. Along with showcasing local talents, Gallery Desta also sold African and Caribbean decorative items and held artist-focused programming such as “Meet the Artist” receptions and music performances called Sunset Gatherings where internationally acclaimed Nubian musician Hamza El Din performed.

  • Primary Form of Entity: For Profit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts, Music, Multi-disciplinary
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter/Distributor

text.headline: Nordic Heritage Museum/National Nordic Museum
text.text:
The Nordic Heritage Museum opened in 1980 in the Ballard neighborhood in the former Webster School, which was rented from Seattle Public Schools. The Nordic Heritage Museum is dedicated to preserving and sharing Nordic and Nordic American culture and does so through folk arts programs, educational programs and exhibitions. In 1993, it was recognized as the only Nordic museum in North America. The lack of a proper climate control system and other building limitations caused the Nordic Heritage Museum to seek a new location. Starting in 2003 the museum began to raise funds and acquire land in Ballard, retaining its connection to this neighborhood founded by Nordic immigrants. After a long fundraising and building process, the new National Nordic Museum opened on May 5, 2018.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Crafts, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Arts Education: Children and Youth, Arts Education: Adults

text.headline: Kreielsheimer Foundation
text.text:
Kreielsheimer Foundation was established by joint bequests of the estates of Leo T. Kreielsheimer (d. 1975) and his wife, Greye McCormick Kreielsheimer (d. 1980). Its first grants were given in 1981, eventually giving nearly $100 million to Seattle area arts and education organizations before ceasing operation in 2000, 25 years after Leo Kreielsheimer's death, as per his wishes.

text.headline: Nippon Kan Theatre
text.text:
The Nippon Kan (Japanese Hall) Theatre originally opened in 1909 as a community and theater space below the Astor Hotel in Seattle's International District. The Nippon Kan Theatre was closed through World War II during the internment of Japanese Americans. The theatre was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1978 and reopened to the public in 1981 after a renovation led by Seattle architect Edward Burke. Many different performances and community gatherings took place at the Nippon Kan, but it remained especially significant to Seattle's Asian and Pacific Islander community and other BIPOC communities because of the opportunities it made possible for them. In 2005, the Nippon Kan was closed when the building was sold as office space to ABC Legal Services.

text.headline: New City Theatre
text.text:
New City Theatre is an artist-run, alternative theater founded in the Capitol Hill neighborhood in 1982. Operating under leadership of longtime collaborators and spouses, director John Kazanjian and performer Mary Ewald, New City is dedicated to being “poor theater,” creating engaging, artistic works of theatre that are affordable and inclusive.
Over its more than thirty years, New City Theatre has occupied at least four different Capitol Hill venues: a 13th Avenue renovated 1904 apartment building; the First Christian Church on Broadway; the SODO Warehouse on Airport Way; and a space on 18th and Union.

text.headline: Dance Theatre Seattle/Bill Evans Dance Company
text.text:
In 1976 noted dancer, choreographer, and educator Bill Evans moved to Seattle, opening Dance Theatre Seattle, the largest and most influential school of contemporary dance in the Pacific Northwest at that time, and performing with his Bill Evans Dance Company. Dance Theatre Seattle closed in 1983, leaving a lasting influence on contemporary dance in the region.

text.headline: Greg Kucera Gallery
text.text:
Greg Kucera Gallery was created in 1983 by Greg Kucera with a commitment to retaining a fresh sensibility to changes in contemporary art, locally and beyond. Over the decades it developed a national reputation with its presentation of the work of hundreds of artists at its venues in Pioneer Square and through national art fairs. The gallery has had a consistent presence in the arts community that continued when ownership shifted to long-time employee Jim Wolcox in 2021.

text.headline: and/or
text.text:
and/or was founded in 1974 by Anne Focke and a collective group of artists in Seattle's Capitol Hill neighborhood. It was the first alternative art space in the Northwest for performances, exhibitions, and other experimental art forms that could not be seen otherwise, and was nationally recognized as an influential arts entity. In 1984 and/or intentionally disbanded, resulting in offshoots like CoCA, Artist Trust, Artech, and 911 Media Arts taking on independent status.

text.headline: Alice B. Theatre
text.text:
When the Alice B. Theatre was founded in 1984, it became Seattle's first theater ensemble focused solely on work by gay and lesbian playwrights. The company would go on to produce radical and high-camp material, while also employing a mix of styles to make the seasons accessible to all theatergoers. Alice B. Theatre never owned a theater facility but produced full seasons of diverse programming at both the Broadway Performance Hall and at Theatre Off Jackson. The Alice B. Theatre was disbanded in the spring of 1996 and briefly reorganized under the title Alice B. Arts, but the company ceased operations fully in 1997.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Producer/Creator, Presenter/Distributor, Venue/Facility

text.headline: 911 Media Center
text.text:
911 Media Arts Center (initially called Focal Point Media Center), an offshoot of and/or, was founded in 1984 by Anne Focke, Heather Dew Oaksen, Jill Medvedow, Norie Sato and others. 911 Media Arts Center supported new-media production and education, with screenings, workshops, and equipment access. It also partnered with many Seattle civic and arts organizations, such as the City of Seattle, Seattle Art Museum, Wing Luke Museum, and the Museum of History and Industry, until its closure in 2014.

text.headline: KRAB-FM
text.text:
Lorenzo Milam founded the subscriber-based, freeform community radio station KRAB 107.7 FM Seattle in 1962, and it was run under the Jack Straw Memorial Foundation from 1964 until going off-air for good in 1984. It was only the fourth commercial-free, listener-supported radio station in the United States and became known for an exceptionally wide variety of programming and occasional troubles with the FCC. The Jack Straw Memorial Foundation later established a community radio station in Snohomish County in 1991, KSER-FM. The Foundation also continues to exist, and still operates the Jack Straw Cultural Center as of 2022.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit

text.headline: Teen Dance Ordinance
text.text:
The Teen Dance Ordinance (TDO) was passed by the Seattle City Council in 1985 to stop abuses at underage clubs, resulting in constricted access to live music for teens in Seattle. The repeal of the ordinance was a key goal of JAMPAC (Joint Artists & Music Promotions Action Committee) founded in 1995. An All-ages Dance Ordinance, written by members of the Music and Youth Task Force, was passed in 2002, replacing the TDO.

text.headline: Annex Theatre
text.text:
Annex Theatre, a democratic collective of theatre artists, was officially created in 1986 on Bainbridge Island. The theatre moved to Seattle in 1988, where it produces five premieres annually and has presented over 300 individual performances. They accept submissions and proposals for new performances annually and the final productions are chosen collectively by the company. Along with traditional theatre, Annex produces late-night shows on a monthly basis, and Spin the Bottle, Seattle's longest-running variety show, that premiered in 1997.

text.headline: Thompson's Point of View
text.text:
Thompson's Point of View was a Central District restaurant known for its Northern Louisiana Soul Food, but more so for its role as a neighborhood gathering place. Proprietor and community leader Carl Thompson, Jr. opened the business in 1986. It served as a cultural hub and venue for live Funk, Hip Hop, Soul, and R&B until its closure in 2011, a year after Carl Jr. passed away suddenly at the age of 51.

text.headline: Theatre Off Jackson
text.text:
Northwest Asian American Theatre (NWAAT), under the leadership of Bea Kiyohara, renovated a former garage into Theatre Off Jackson in Seattle's International District in 1987. Following the closure of NWAAT in 2004 the 140-seat theater has served as a performance space for small arts groups and independent artists presenting plays, music, film, readings and other events using a production partnership model.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit

text.headline: Sub Pop Records
text.text:
Independent Seattle record label Sub Pop Records was founded by Bruce Pavitt and Jonathan Poneman in 1988, achieving international attention and fame with Seattle grunge bands including Nirvana, Soundgarden and Mudhoney. The label’s influential role in the record industry continued with music releases in a range of genres.

text.headline: Hedgebrook
text.text:
Hedgebrook opened its first session of writing residencies in 1988, offering opportunities for women writers to work and live in cottages on rural Whidbey Island. Seattle philanthropist Nancy Nordhoff established Hedgebrook with a gift of the property. The nonprofit organization hosts women writers from around the globe working in many genres, and offers ancillary programs on site and around the country.

text.headline: Seattle Public Theater
text.text:
Established in 1989, Seattle Public Theater is a nonprofit theater housed in the City of Seattle's historic Bathhouse Theater building located in Green Lake Park. Seattle Public Theater is focused on producing and presenting socially relevant theater.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theater

text.headline: Goodwill Arts Festival
text.text:
Held in conjunction with 1990 Seattle Goodwill Games, the month-long Goodwill Arts Festival brought major works of performing and visual arts from Russia, including the Bolshoi Ballet, Prokofiev's opera "War and Peace", an exhibition of Russian treasures and "Art Into Life: Russian Constructivism 1914-1932" as well as contemporary arts projects in theatre and the visual arts in collaboration with local arts institutions and artists. The arts festival was considered a major success, overshadowing the Goodwill Games.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit; Governmental
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre, Music, Dance, Visual Arts, Design, Multidisciplinary
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter, Festival/Event, Services for Organizations, Services for Artists

text.headline: Pat Graney Company
text.text:
Pat Graney Company incorporated in 1990 to present the choreography of Pat Graney locally, nationally and abroad. Her work features a variety of boundary pushing dance vocabularies from gymnastics and martial arts, to artistic innovations in women’s prisons and explorations of female identity and power.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Dance
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Producer/Creator

Research and Resources

Visit Seattle Public Theater

text.headline: Re-bar
text.text:
Re-bar opened in 1990 by co-founders Steve Wells and Patrick “Pit” Kweicinski. Their aim was to create a welcoming place for people of all sexualities, genders, and artistic tastes. During their 30 years in operation, a reputation was earned for hosting a wide range of musical experiences, including new artists and widely attended dance nights. Re-bar has been considered one of the last holdouts of Seattle's indie theatre/nightclubs, critical to the city's LGBT and arts scenes. They closed in 2020 with the intent to reopen in South Seattle sometime in the future.

  • Primary Form of Entity: For Profit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre, Dance, Music, Cabaret
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Venue/Facility

text.headline: Seattle Fringe Festival
text.text:
The first successful Seattle Fringe Festival took place in 1991, after the establishment of the League of Fringe Theaters in 1989. The event continued off and on for two decades, changing formats, programming, and leadership several times and producing many festivals and collaborations. It has influenced festivals, film, theater, and other events ever since. During their time, SFF hosted an eclectic mix of local and national artists and companies, as well as acts from around the world. The festival most recently ceased operations in 2018, with future plans to be determined.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre

text.headline: Building for the Arts
text.text:
Building for the Arts was created by the Washington State Legislature in 1991 to award grants to performing arts, art museum, and cultural organizations for up to 20 percent of eligible capital costs for acquisition, construction, and/or major renovation of capital facilities. The reimbursement-style grants are funded by the sale of state bonds only. Awardees are selected through a competitive grant application process held every two years.

text.headline: Seattle Art Museum
text.text:
The Seattle Art Museum (SAM) opened in Volunteer Park in 1933 under founder Dr. Richard E. Fuller. The museum presented modern art and changing exhibitions at the Seattle Art Museum Pavilion at the Seattle Center from 1963 until the museum's move to its present downtown location in Seattle in 1991. A landmark exhibition, Treasures of Tutankhamun, at Seattle Center in 1978 helped to fuel plans for the expansion of the museum to downtown. The Volunteer Park facility was rededicated as the Seattle Asian Art Museum (SAAM)in 1994 focusing on the museum's extensive Asian collections, and underwent a renovation and expansion in 2020. In 2007 a substantial expansion doubled space at the downtown facility, and the museum's Olympic Sculpture Park opened on Seattle's waterfront. SAM's three facilities are home to nearly 25,000 pieces of art from a range of time periods and global cultures.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts, Media Arts, Design, Crafts, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter, Arts Education: Children and Youth, Arts Education: Adults, Venue/Facility

text.headline: Summer Nights on the Pier
text.text:
Starting in 1991 an annual summer series of touring music shows were presented on City of Seattle-owned Piers 62/63. The popular series, produced by One Reel, ended in 2005 due to safety concerns with the deteriorating piers.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Governmental, Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Music
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter, Venue/Facility

text.headline: Red Eagle Soaring
text.text:
Red Eagle Soaring integrates contemporary theatre and traditional Native performing arts and has mentored hundreds of Native youth and staged scores of productions since being founded in 1991. Their focus is on facilitating access to Native cultural traditions and promoting social, physical, and intellectual engagement. The organization aims to build community among Native youth by bringing them together to learn the technical aspects of theater and by sharing, promoting, and supporting Native art and culture.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theater, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Arts Education: Children and Youth, Arts Presenter/Distributor

text.headline: Raven Chronicles Press
text.text:
Raven Chronicles Press is a nonprofit independent publishing press and literary organization. A Seattle-based journal of art and literature, they publish the work of traditional storytellers, as well as experimental and emerging works. Raven Chronicles was founded as a literary journal by Kathleen Alcalá, Phoebe Bosché, and Philip H. Red Eagle in 1991 and went on to publish forty-eight issues from 1991 to 2018. In 1997, they began a partnership with Richard Hugo House in Seattle's Capitol Hill neighborhood that lasted a decade. In 2016 Raven Chronicles became Raven Chronicles Press, an independent micro-publishing house that focuses on anthologies.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Literary Arts
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter/distributor, service(s) for artists

Research and Resources

Visit Raven Chronicles Press

text.headline: Economic Impact Study of Arts and Culture
text.text:
The first study of the economic impact of arts and culture in King County was commissioned by Corporate Council for the Arts (later ArtsFund) in 1992. It provided new insights into the region's arts and heritage organizations, patrons, and models for measuring related economic impact. Further studies have been commissioned approximately every five years, providing important data for arts policy, funding, and advocacy.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Multidisciplinary
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Arts Policy/Advocacy, Arts Funding

text.headline: African American Heritage Museum and Cultural Center
text.text:
African American Heritage Museum and Cultural Center was formed in 1993 as a nonprofit, with support from the City of Seattle. The former Colman School building was purchased from the Seattle School District and the Northwest African American Museum (NAAM) opened its doors in 2008 to present and preserve the connections between the Pacific Northwest and people of African descent, and to Investigate and celebrate Black experiences in America through exhibitions, programs and events.

text.headline: Seattle Children's Theatre
text.text:
The Seattle Children's Theatre (SCT) brings professional theater and theater education to children and youth in the greater Puget Sound region. After starting out at the PONCHO Theatre on the grounds of the Woodland Park Zoo, and being officially founded in 1975, SCT moved in 1993 to its newly built Charlotte Martin Theatre at Seattle Center, under Artistic Director Linda Hartzell. Nationally and internationally recognized for its commitment to new works, SCT's 482-seat and 275-seat theaters are also home to the SCT Drama School.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit

text.headline: Frye Art Museum
text.text:
The Frye Art Museum opened in 1952 in Seattle' First Hill neighborhood providing free public access to business leaders Charles and Emma Frye's predominantly nineteenth century art collection. The Frye's executor, Walser Greathouse, led the museum from its inception and, upon his death, it was led by his wife, Ida Kay Greathouse. New museum leadership in 1994, and the 1997 expansion and renovation of the museum, marked a shift towards increasing engagement with modern and contemporary art and artists, locally and internationally, while the Frye's Founding Collection remains on view.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts, Multidisciplinary Arts

text.text:
The original 1933 Volunteer Park art deco building of the Seattle Art Museum (SAM) was reopened as the Seattle Asian Art Museum (SAAM) in 1994, focusing on the museum's Asian collections, special exhibitions, and related programs, with SAM's main collections located in the museum's downtown facility. Additional renovations and expansion of SAAM occurred in 2017.

text.headline: Seattle Theater Group
text.text:
The Seattle Theater Group (STG) began in 1994 when Ida Cole purchased the historic but financially distressed Paramount Theatre and re-established the non-profit Seattle Landmark Association. The Seattle Landmark Association became STG, embracing stewardship of three historic theaters: The Paramount, The Moore, and The Neptune. An average of 700 events are produced annually in these facilities from Broadway productions, concerts, dance, theatre and film, to lectures, education and community programs.

text.headline: Joint Artists and Music Promotions Political Action Committee (JAMPAC)
text.text:
The Teen Dance Ordinance (TDO) was passed by the Seattle City Council in 1985 to stop abuses at underage clubs, resulting in constricted access to live music for teens in Seattle. The repeal of the ordinance was a key goal of JAMPAC (Joint Artists & Music Promotions Action Committee) founded in 1995. An All-ages Dance Ordinance, written by members of the Music and Youth Task Force, was passed in 2002, replacing the TDO.

text.headline: SOIL Art Gallery
text.text:
SOIL was formed as a nonprofit artist cooperative to provide an alternative venue for Seattle area artists to exhibit and develop their work. SOIL has been entirely artist run since its founding in 1995, presenting new exhibits monthly and helping to develop careers of many of its members who then moved on to other galleries and venues. The Tashiro Kaplan Building in Pioneer Square became SOIL's long-term home in 2004.

Northwest Film Forum (NWFF) was founded by a collective of Seattle filmmakers in 1995 (as WgglyWorld) taking on the operation of the Grand Illusion Cinema for a period of time, and growing to encompass both film production and presentation. In 2003 NWFF moved to a larger space on Capitol Hill housing its film center and related programs and services.

text.headline: LEMS (Life Enrichment) Bookstore
text.text:
Life Enrichment Bookstore, a black-owned business, community gathering space, and cultural hub in Columbia City, Seattle, was founded by Vickie Williams in the late 1990s. It closed in 2017 after her death, but it reopened in 2020 through efforts by her granddaughter Sister Tylicia Messiah. The vision remains to establish cultural connection and build generational bonds within the greater Seattle area African American communities.

text.headline: Velocity Dance Center
text.text:
Founded in 1996 by KT Niehoff and Michele Miller, the Velocity Dance Center provides training, classes, and rehearsal space to the greater Puget Sound area contemporary dance community. Velocity relocated from the Odd Fellows building on Capitol Hill to its nearby home on 12th Avenue in 2010. Significant program growth occurred under the leadership of Tonya Lockyer and other leaders, expanding Velocity's contributions to the national and international field of dance. In December of 2020, Velocity left their Capitol Hill home due to financial issues that were largely exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic while continuing to look for a new physical location.

text.headline: Dr. James and Janie Washington Cultural Center
text.text:
Dr. James Washington (1911-2000) was an acclaimed Northwest painter and sculptor. The craftsman bungalow home in the Central District where he lived with his wife, Janie Rogella Washington, was also his studio. In 1992 the City of Seattle designated it as an historical landmark. After Janie Washington's death in 2000, and through the support of the James and Janie Washington Foundation (est. 1997), it became a museum and cultural center preserving his legacy, holding events to inspire creativity and build community, and providing an artist-in-residence program.

text.headline: Seattle Center Festal Cultural Festivals
text.text:
Seattle Center Festal, a joint community and city led effort, was founded in 1997 as an opportunity to highlight the diverse cultures of the region through cultural festivals. These free weekend festivals have grown over the last twenty years to include 23 ethnic communities and continue Seattle Center's role as a public community space. Seattle Center helps to produce and promote the year-round program of festivals, collaborating with intergenerational teams in each community. As of 2021, some of the festivals that are a part of Festal are: Festival Sundiata, Northwest Folklife Festival, Irish Festival Seattle, the Polish Festival, Brasilfest, Sea Mar Fiestas Patrias, and the Italian Festival.

text.headline: Alice B. Theatre
text.text:
When the Alice B. Theatre was founded in 1984, it became Seattle's first theater ensemble focused solely on work by gay and lesbian playwrights. The company would go on to produce radical and high-camp material, while also employing a mix of styles to make the seasons accessible to all theatergoers. Alice B. Theatre never owned a theater facility but produced full seasons of diverse programming at both the Broadway Performance Hall and at Theatre Off Jackson. The Alice B. Theatre was disbanded in the spring of 1996 and briefly reorganized under the title Alice B. Arts, but the company ceased operations fully in 1997.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Producer/Creator, Presenter/Distributor, Venue/Facility

text.headline: El Centro de la Raza
text.text:
El Centro de la Raza was founded in October 1972 as the result of a 75-day peaceful occupation of the abandoned Beacon Hill School. The occupation led to negotiations with the Mayor's office and resulted in the City agreeing to sublease the building to El Centro de la Raza for $1 a year. El Centro de la Raza was initially inspired by the desire and need for a hub for the Latino community in Seattle but evolved to become a multi-cultural organization. Founder Roberto Maestas served as the Executive Director until 2009. El Centro de la Raza provides many social and other services to people in need and uses the arts as a means of social change and activism. Arts-related programming includes an art and mural gallery and features traditional art and artists in larger events. In 1997, the school district raised the rent to the market rate of $12,000/month, but $1 million in grants from the City of Seattle and Washington state helped El Centro de la Raza purchase the building from the school district.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts

text.headline: Rainier Valley Cultural Center
text.text:
The Rainier Valley Cultural Center was purchased by South East Effective Development (SEED) in 1995 as a multicultural community performance space and opened its doors in 1997. The 1921 former church space provides performance opportunities, workshops, and summer camps for local youth, and the Center produces an annual Summer Series of outdoor movies, concerts, and plays in Columbia Park. The focus is on serving the ethnically diverse Rainier Valley community. In 2015 the name was changed to the Rainier Arts Center.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Governmental
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theater, Music, Dance
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Venue/Facility

text.headline: Umoja Fest/African Heritage Festival and Parade
text.text:
Umoja Fest/African Heritage Festival and Parade has been a celebration of ethnic diversity showcasing local, national and international artists in Seattle since the 1940s. Dedicated to highlighting the countless contributions of African Americans, Umoja Fest originally developed from the International Festival of the 1940s and has seen many transformations over the decades. In 1952, it became known as the East Madison/East Union Mardi Gras Festival. The name changed to the Pacific Northwest Black Community Festival in the 1960s, and since 1997, it has been known as Umoja Fest/African Heritage Festival and Parade.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Music, Dance, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts, Multidisciplinary
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Arts Education: Children and Youth, Arts Education: Adults, Arts in Social Service/Social Justice, Arts in Community Development, Festival/Event.

text.headline: Suyama Space
text.text:
Suyama Space was founded in 1997 by architect George Suyama and curator Beth Sellars. It closed its doors on December 16th, 2016, after presenting notable site-specific installations by numerous contemporary local, regional, and national artists. The Belltown gallery was free to the public, and it dedicated all donations and grant money towards materials and artists' stipends.

Suyama Space specialized in art tailored to the space itself - hence the name. Sellars and Suyama invited artists to create work for the space three times a year. The art ranged from formal to architectural, from political to theatrical. Suyama Peterson Deguchi: Northwest Contemporary Design operated in the same building as the Suyama Space. A 2017 publication, Suyama Space, 1998-2017, documents all the installations from its nineteen-year history.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts, Design
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Facility/Venue.

text.headline: Group Theatre Company
text.text:
Started in 1978, Seattle Group Theatre Company was one of the first multicultural theater companies in the country and a leader in the movement for multicultural and inclusive casting, under Founding Artistic Director Ruben Sierra. Housed at the University of Washington's Ethnic Cultural Theatre from 1978 to 1992, The Group as it was locally known, moved to the Center House Theatre at Seattle Center in 1993 and resided there until 1998. The Group closed its doors in 1998 having presented the works of many Black, Asian, and Latino playwrights, directors, and actors.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Governmental; Nonprofit

  • Primary Areas of Activity: Producer/Creator, Venue/Facility, Arts in Social Justice

text.headline: Richard Hugo House
text.text:
An idea by three writers to create an urban writer’s center resulted in the opening of Richard Hugo House on Capitol Hill in 1998. Named for Northwest poet Richard Hugo, Hugo House provides classes, readings, and opportunities for writers working in a range of genres, from the region and far beyond. A new permanent Capitol Hill home for Hugo House opened in September 2018.

  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Literary

text.headline: On The Boards
text.text:
On the Boards (OtB) was founded in 1978 to produce and present unique performance projects by leading contemporary artists. It was based in Washington Hall until 1998 when it moved into its own venue in lower Queen Anne, where its annual programming includes works by international, national and local artists.

text.headline: Benaroya Hall
text.text:
Benaroya Hall, home of the Seattle Symphony, opened its doors in 1998 in downtown Seattle with two performance halls: a 2500-seat performance venue, as well as a recital hall seating 536. The building was designed by LMN Architects and named for Seattle philanthropist Jack Benaroya, a significant donor to the capital campaign that raised $159 million in private funds — the largest amount raised to that time by an arts organization in the State of Washington. Its downtown location is credited with revitalizing the city center.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Music, Multidisciplinary
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter, Venue/Facility

text.headline: Seattle Symphony
text.text:
The Seattle Symphony inaugurated its new permanent home, Benaroya Hall in downtown Seattle in 1998. This was followed by the opening of Soundbridge: Seattle Symphony Music Discovery Center, which was renovated and renamed Octave 9: Raisbeck Music Center in 2019. Founded in 1903, the Seattle Symphony gained increasing national and international attention under Music Directors Gerard Schwartz (1985 to 2010) and Ludovic Morlot (2011 to 2018). Programming includes an annual season of orchestral works, a strong commitment to new music, community-minded initiatives, and over 150 recordings that have garnered Grammy Awards, Emmy Awards and other recognition.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Music
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Producer/Creator, Venue/Facility, Presenter/Distributor

text.headline: Seattle Public Library "Libraries for All"
text.text:
Seattle’s "Libraries for All" bond measure was passed by a significant majority of voters in November 1998 to upgrade Seattle Public Library's system with new facilities, technology, and books. Bill and Melinda Gates donated $20 million, the largest gift to a public library in American history, and the Library Foundation pledged to raise additional funds. When the capital plan was completed in 2008 it included the new Rem Koolhaas-designed central library downtown as well twenty-six new, replaced, and renovated branch libraries in every corner of the city.

text.headline: Town Hall Seattle
text.text:
Founded in 1998, Town Hall Seattle is a nonprofit cultural center and performance hall housed inside the landmark Fourth Church of Christ, Scientist building constructed in 1922. Town Hall purchased the building in 1998 with the assistance of Historic Seattle Preservation and Development Authority. Town Hall serves as a venue for programs including civics, arts and culture, science, and other community uses for the greater Seattle area. A $20 million renovation project concluded in May of 2019.

The Central District Forum for Arts & Ideas (CD Forum) was founded in 1999 by Stephanie Ellis-Smith to encourage thought and debate around African American art and culture. CD Forum serves audiences throughout the greater Seattle area as a platform for local and national arts and humanities programming through the lens of the Black experience.

text.text:

text.headline: Consolidated Works
text.text:
Consolidated Works, under the leadership of Matthew Richter and Meg Shiffler, opened in 1999 in former warehouses in the South Lake Union neighborhood of Seattle. This inter-and multidisciplinary arts center hosted theater, film, visual art, music, lectures and events in a space integrating an art gallery, a theater, a cinema, an event hall, and several studio spaces. With the impending loss of the lease on their 29,000-foot space owned by Vulcan Real Estate, and after an internal restructuring, Consolidated Works shut down in 2006.

text.headline: Paramount Theater
text.text:
The Seattle Children's Theatre (SCT) brings professional theater and theater education to children and youth in the greater Puget Sound region. After starting out at the PONCHO Theatre on the grounds of the Woodland Park Zoo, and being officially founded in 1975, SCT moved in 1993 to its newly built Charlotte Martin Theatre at Seattle Center, under Artistic Director Linda Hartzell. Nationally and internationally recognized for its commitment to new works, SCT's 482-seat and 275-seat theaters are also home to the SCT Drama School.

text.headline: Massive Monkees/The Beacon
text.text:
Massive Monkees is a Seattle based breakdance and hip hop crew that began creating hip hop shows for theater in the late 1990's. The crew consists of dancers, graffiti artists, DJs and general support members who are mostly from Seattle's South End. Massive Monkees creates full length theater production, participates in battle style dance competitions, and has performed with major musical acts such as Macklemore, Jay-Z, Missy Elliott, Public Enemy and more, and were featured on America's Best Dance Crew. Massive Monkees opened their studio The Beacon as a part of Shunpike's Storefronts Seattle in 2013. The Beacon provided art-based programs for the neighborhood and surrounding community in the International District to encourage creative expression and positive change. The Beacon lost its location in November 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and as of 2021 Massive Monkees are still seeking a new studio location.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit, For Profit Business

Art Corps' nationally- recognized youth arts education emphasizes a culturally diverse approach to learning and includes K-12 arts programming led by teaching artists primarily in the South Seattle and South King County, out-of-school arts (such as a mural program in SoDO), and teen leadership programs.

text.headline: Kreielsheimer Foundation
text.text:
Kreielsheimer Foundation was established by joint bequests of the estates of Leo T. Kreielsheimer (d. 1975) and his wife, Greye McCormick Kreielsheimer (d. 1980). Its first grants were given in 1981, eventually giving nearly $100 million to Seattle area arts and education organizations before ceasing operation in 2000, 25 years after Leo Kreielsheimer's death, as per his wishes.

text.headline: Experience Music Project/Museum of Pop Culture (MoPOP)
text.text:
The Experience Music Project opened at Seattle Center on June 23, 2000. The project had been spearheaded by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, who wanted to dedicate a museum to Seattle-born rock guitarist Jimi Hendrix. It is housed in a distinctive building designed by architect Frank O. Gehry. It has been renamed several times but has been called the Museum of Pop Culture (MoPOP) since 2016. Besides music, exhibits have also featured sci-fi, fashion, horror movies, video games, and pop culture.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit

text.headline: SIS Productions
text.text:
Active since 2000, the all-volunteer run production company SIS Productions creates, develops, and produces works that involve Asian American women and center Asian American. The organization provides opportunities and support for Asian American women in all aspects of production, leadership and decision-making positions. They have been involved with Represent! Multicultural Playwrights' Festival and other performances at LANGSTON, Hugo House, and the Bathhouse Theater, among others. A SIS Writers Group was established in 2005, and SIS created a Celebrate Women campaign in 2014 to inspire people of all genders, ages and races to re-imagine how women are valued in our society.

  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theater

text.headline: The Vera Project
text.text:
The Vera Project was founded as an all-ages, volunteer-fueled music and arts venue in Seattle by James Keblas, Shannon Stewart, and Kate Becker in 2001 in response to the restrictions on youth access to popular music concerts due to the Teen Dance Ordinance. Programming was held in a variety of sites expanding to include visual arts, sound engineering, and musicians’ resources. Vera moved into its long-term home at Seattle Center 2007, continuing its volunteer-fueled participatory approach that has garnered national and international attention.

text.headline: Conciliation Project
text.text:
In 2001, Dr. Tawnya Pettiford-Wates developed the idea for The Conciliation Project during an interdisciplinary theatre class at Seattle Central Community College as she grappled with how to present deconstructed Black stories (namely, those found in “Uncle Tom's Cabin”) on stage without a cast of Black students. The unexpectedly robust response to the deconstructed retelling of the classic novel gave birth to The Conciliation Project, which offers workshops, trainings and performances geared toward businesses, organizations, schools and communities to help in the process of eliminating racial and cultural stereotypes. The Conciliation Project was based in Seattle until 2005, when Dr. Pettiford-Wates relocated to Richmond, Virginia where the Conciliation Project continues.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Arts in Social Service/Social Justice, Producer/Creator, Presenter/Distributor

text.headline: Reel Grrls
text.text:
Founded in 2001 by Malory Graham, Reel Grrls was a non-profit media arts organization dedicated to teaching young women and teens the skills needed to make their own films and videos. Reel Grrls closed its doors in 2020.
Reel Grrls provided media literacy training to help youth from diverse communities interpret and respond to the flood of gendered and racialized images and messages young people encounter. Through after-school sessions, day camps, and weekend workshops, they taught students ages 15-22 to write scripts, shoot film and video, and create a finished visual story. Reel Grrls productions have been screened at film festivals around the world and participants have gone on to careers in the media industry.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Media arts, Arts reporting/criticism
  • Primary Areas of Activity: arts education: children and youth, arts in community development, producer/creator

text.headline: City of Seattle Teen Dance Ordinance
text.text:
The Teen Dance Ordinance (TDO) was passed by the Seattle City Council in 1985 to stop abuses at underage clubs, resulting in constricted access to live music for teens in Seattle. The repeal of the ordinance was a key goal of JAMPAC (Joint Artists & Music Promotions Action Committee) founded in 1995. An All-ages Dance Ordinance, written by members of the Music and Youth Task Force, was passed in 2002, replacing the TDO.

text.text:

Van Cliburn performed Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3 and Igor Stravinsky conducted the Seattle Symphony in a performance of his Firebird Suite. In 2003 the building was significantly refurbished and reopened as Marion Oliver McCaw Hall.

Founded in 1965 to support arts and culture in King County, the King County Arts Commission later became the King County Office of Cultural Resources, and then 4 Culture, a Public Development Authority (PDA) in 2003. 4Culture supports four program areas: arts, heritage, preservation, and public art and offers grants and artist calls.

text.headline: City of Seattle Office of Film + Music
text.text:
The City of Seattle Office of Economic Development expanded to house the Office of Film + Music (OF+M), producing two studies in 2003 of the economic impact of the music industry in Seattle. OF+M created the Seattle Music Commission, developed a City of Music 2020 Vision, and develops economic and cultural policy to support film and music business growth, including the nightlife industry and permitting for film and special events.

text.headline: Japanese Cultural and Community Center of WA
text.text:
Since its establishment in 2003, the Japanese Cultural and Community Center of Washington (JCCCW) has been a hub for Japanese history, heritage, and culture for residents of Seattle and beyond. Located on the site of the original Seattle Japanese Language School, which was founded in 1902, the JCCCW is not only dedicated to preserving cultural knowledge but also to building and supporting the community around it. The JCCCW offers classes, events, and cultural programming to youth and adults and has been recognized as a critical support structure for the Japanese and Japanese American community in the city since its inception.
