text.headline: Northwest Asian American Theatre (NWAAT)
text.text:
Originally founded by a group of Asian American students in 1972 on the University of Washington campus at the school's Ethnic Cultural Center Northwest Asian American Theatre became a flagship Asian American theatre company in the Pacific Northwest and the first of its kind in the region. In 1987, after the ensemble students graduated from the University of Washington, NWAAT moved theater operations into an automobile repair shop and converted this garage space into the Theatre Off Jackson, a 140-seat venue that still provides performance space to a rotating number of groups. Bea Kiyohara served as Artistic Director of NWAAT for most of the company's existence, from 1978 until 1993. NWAAT was celebrated for producing work that connected with a diverse audience and for supporting local APA actors, directors, and playwrights who went on to great success after their time at NWAAT. The Northwest Asian American Theatre closed its doors in 2004.

text.headline: Longhouse Media
text.text:
Longhouse Media was co-founded in 2005 by Tracy Rector and Annie Silverstein. Its signature youth program, Native Lens, was established in 2003 by 911 Media Arts Center in partnership with the Swinomish Indian Tribal Community as a model media literacy program for Native youth. Longhouse Media is an Indigenous media arts organization that nurtures the expression and development of Native artists through traditional and modern forms of storytelling, with an emphasis on cultural identity. It supports the use of media as a tool for self-expression, cultural preservation, and social change.

text.headline: Nippon Kan Theatre
text.text:
The Nippon Kan (Japanese Hall) Theatre originally opened in 1909 as a community and theater space below the Astor Hotel in Seattle's International District. The Nippon Kan Theatre was closed through World War II during the internment of Japanese Americans. The theatre was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1978 and reopened to the public in 1981 after a renovation led by Seattle architect Edward Burke. Many different performances and community gatherings took place at the Nippon Kan, but it remained especially significant to Seattle's Asian and Pacific Islander community and other BIPOC communities because of the opportunities it made possible for them. In 2005, the Nippon Kan was closed when the building was sold as office space to ABC Legal Services.

  • Primary Form of Entity: For Profit, Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Folk/Traditional/Heritage arts, Theatre, Music, Dance
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Venue/Facility, Arts in Community Development

text.headline: Northwest Tap Connection
text.text:
Northwest Tap Connection began when founder Melba Ayco took over Darryln Smith's studio, Central TTAAPP (Talent, Tap, Acting Arts, Performance, Production) in 2002 after Smith's death, but it was not officially formed until 2005. Northwest Tap Connection specializes in Rhythm Tap but also offers dance classes in multiple styles for both children and adults and produces community events. Northwest Tap Connection's main mission is to center Black and Brown artists through social justice-inspired work. In 2018, Northwest Tap Connection purchased another building in order to expand their offerings and programming.

  • Primary Form of Entity: For Profit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Dance
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Arts education: Children and Youth, Arts in Community Development, Producer/creator

text.headline: Gallery Onyx/Onyx Fine Arts Collective
text.text:
In operation since 2005, Onyx Fine Arts Collective and its volunteer-run Gallery Onyx are committed to celebrating and promoting the visual artwork of Pacific Northwest artists of African descent. Gallery Onyx moved from Belltown to Pacific Place in 2018 and features rotating exhibits that are representative of the African diaspora, especially in Seattle.

text.headline: Spirit of Africa Festival
text.text:
Spirit of Africa Festival (formerly known as the Spirit of West Africa), a free, annual one-day event at the Seattle Center Armory, was founded in 2005 and produced by local Senegalese griot musician Thione Diop. It celebrates the music, dance, and culture of Africa and the diaspora in partnership with Festal.

text.headline: City Arts
text.text:
City Arts produces a monthly print magazine as well as online content and events focused on the arts and culture of the Seattle area, reporting on a range of creative disciplines and genres. Founded in Tacoma in 2006, City Arts began as a product of Encore Media Group, the Northwest-based custom publishing company producing Encore Arts Programs for major performing arts organizations. In 2018 City Arts ceased operating due to a lack of funding.

text.headline: The Hansberry Project
text.text:
Named after activist and playwright, Lorrain Hansberry, The Hansberry Project began producing, supporting, and nurturing Black Theater and voices in 2006. The Hansberry Project has supported artists in varying career levels through mentorships and community outreach that centers Black artists and their artistic process. Co-founded by Valerie Curtis-Newton and Vivian Phillips, The Hansberry Project supports works that reflect “the richness and diversity of American life”.

text.headline: Consolidated Works
text.text:
Consolidated Works, under the leadership of Matthew Richter and Meg Shiffler, opened in 1999 in former warehouses in the South Lake Union neighborhood of Seattle. This inter-and multidisciplinary arts center hosted theater, film, visual art, music, lectures and events in a space integrating an art gallery, a theater, a cinema, an event hall, and several studio spaces. With the impending loss of the lease on their 29,000-foot space owned by Vulcan Real Estate, and after an internal restructuring, Consolidated Works shut down in 2006.

text.headline: Empty Space Theatre
text.text:
Founded in 1971 by University of Washington Drama department graduates, under director M. Burke Walker, the Empty Space Theatre's first home was in the Pike Place Market, moving to Capitol Hill, Pioneer Square, and Fremont before affiliating with Seattle University. It ceased operation in 2006.

text.headline: Equinox Studios
text.text:
Equinox Studios was started in 2006 by Samuel Farrazaino to develop 38 artist and artisan studios in a collaborative community in the Georgetown neighborhood of Seattle. In 2015 Equinox expanded to just under 100,000 square feet of studios, dance rehearsal, performance, and other arts-focused spaces with over 125 tenants, and became tenant owned based on a new model for sustainability.

text.headline: Faire Gallery Café
text.text:
Faire Gallery Café was a small unassuming eatery, jazz lounge, and art space owned and operated by artist and activist Elisheba Johnson. It was a welcoming community gathering place offering a variety of forms of art, live music, dance, theater, comedy and spoken word. After six years on Capitol Hill in Seattle, the business closed in 2012. Seattle Weekly called it one of the “top 5 Seattle restaurants with music on the menu” just a year before its closure.

text.headline: Hidmo
text.text:
Sisters Rahwa and Asmeret Habte bought Hidmo in 2006. They made the former restaurant into a place where meetings and performances took place, including spoken word and all ages hip hop shows, while continuing to serve Eritrean food. While it was a short-lived venture which closed in 2010, Hidmo became a prominent informal cultural hub in the Central District during that time.

text.headline: Olympic Sculpture Park
text.text:
The Seattle Art Museum's nine acre Olympic Sculpture Park opened to the public in 2007 on Seattle’s last undeveloped downtown waterfront property. The museum worked with the Trust for Public Lands, with additional private and public funding. An endowment from Jon and Mary Shirley ensures free entry to the public in perpetuity. This third SAM campus was designed by the New York firm of Weiss/Manfredi melding art, landscape, architecture and infrastructure.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts, Design, Multidisciplinary

text.headline: La Sala
text.text:
La Sala was founded in 2007 as a collective to coalesce and mobilize the growing Latino/Latina arts community of the Seattle region. Founders Irene Gomez, Miguel Guillén, Catalina Cantu and Wendy Call joined with other artists, arts administrators, and advocates, developing programs and opportunities to increase the presence and raise the profile of the region's Latinx artists and artisans.

text.headline: The Vera Project
text.text:
The Vera Project was founded as an all-ages, volunteer-fueled music and arts venue in Seattle by James Keblas, Shannon Stewart, and Kate Becker in 2001 in response to the restrictions on youth access to popular music concerts due to the Teen Dance Ordinance. Programming was held in a variety of sites expanding to include visual arts, sound engineering, and musicians’ resources. Vera moved into its long-term home at Seattle Center 2007, continuing its volunteer-fueled participatory approach that has garnered national and international attention.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Music, Visual Arts, Design, Media Arts, Multidisciplinary

text.headline: Ewajo Dance Studio
text.text:
Ewajo Dance Studio was opened in 1975 in Wallingford by dance teacher Edna Daigre, who was looking for a home for her dance classes blending conditioning, Afro-Latin and jazz dance. Ewajo, which is named after the Yoruba word for “common dance”, had several locations, but moved to the corner of Madison Street and Martin Luther King Jr. Way in 1989. Ewajo Dance Studio closed in 2007 but Chris Daigre, Edna Daigre's son, is still teaching dance classes in Seattle as of 2021.

text.headline: Odd Fellows Hall Building
text.text:
The 1908 Oddfellows Hall Building on Capitol Hill served as the home to a number of nonprofit arts organizations from the 1970s until its sale in 2008 and subsequent rent increases. The second and third floors were originally performance halls, with an additional performance theater on the fourth floor.

text.headline: Wing Luke Museum of the Asian Pacific American Experience
text.text:
Wing Luke Museum was founded in 1967 in the Chinatown International District to focus on the history and culture of Asian Pacific Americans, becoming the only pan-Asian Pacific American community -based museum in the United States. The WING rehabilitated the historic East Kong Yick Building as its expanded home in 2008.

text.headline: Northwest African American Museum
text.text:
African American Heritage Museum and Cultural Center was formed in 1993 as a nonprofit, with support from the City of Seattle. The former Colman School building was purchased from the Seattle School District and the Northwest African American Museum (NAAM) opened its doors in 2008 to present and preserve the connections between the Pacific Northwest and people of African descent, and to Investigate and celebrate Black experiences in America through exhibitions, programs and events.

text.headline: Seattle Public Library "Libraries for All"
text.text:
Seattle’s "Libraries for All" bond measure was passed by a significant majority of voters in November 1998 to upgrade Seattle Public Library's system with new facilities, technology, and books. Bill and Melinda Gates donated $20 million, the largest gift to a public library in American history, and the Library Foundation pledged to raise additional funds. When the capital plan was completed in 2008 it included the new Rem Koolhaas-designed central library downtown as well twenty-six new, replaced, and renovated branch libraries throughout Seattle.

text.headline: Lucid Lounge
text.text:
Lucid Lounge was a Caribbean restaurant, cocktail lounge, and jazz club in Seattle's University District owned by David Pierre-Louis. The space also served as a venue for such events as film screenings, burlesque performances, and lectures. Records indicate that it closed around 2015.

text.headline: Washington Hall
text.text:
Historic Seattle, with the help of 4Culture, purchased Washington Hall in the Central District in 2009 and restored it as a home for community arts, heritage, and cultural organizations, with a rental program focused on performance and community events. Built in 1908 by a Danish brotherhood, the building was sold in 1973 to Sons of Haiti, an African-American Masonic lodge. Washington Hall has hosted speakers including W.E.B. Du Bois, Marcus Garvey, and Martin Luther King, Jr. as well as numerous performers including Ella Fitzgerald, Jimi Hendrix, and David Byrne, and was the home of On the Boards for 20 years. It reopened to the community in June 2016.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit

text.headline: Safeco Art Collection/Washington Art Consortium
text.text:
Safeco, a Seattle-based insurance company, built a major collection of Pacific Northwest art starting in 1973 to enhance their workplace while giving employees insight into Northwest art; to support local artists; and to support local galleries by buying works featured there. The collection was dispersed with over 840 works donated to the Washington Arts Consortium in 2010 after the company became part of Liberty Mutual.

  • Primary Form of Entity: For Profit

  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter, Other: Art Collection

text.headline: Velocity Dance Center
text.text:
Founded in 1996 by KT Niehoff and Michele Miller, the Velocity Dance Center provides training, classes, and rehearsal space to the greater Puget Sound area contemporary dance community. Velocity relocated from the Odd Fellows building on Capitol Hill to its nearby home on 12th Avenue in 2010. Significant program growth occurred under the leadership of Tanya Lockyer and other leaders, expanding Velocity's contributions to the national and international field of dance. In December of 2020, Velocity left their Capitol Hill home due to financial issues that were largely exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic while continuing to look for a new physical location.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit

text.headline: ese Teatro
text.text:
The organization eSe Teatro began in 2010 by Artistic Director Rose Cano and Musical Director Meg Savlov. The organization provides a voice for Latinx artists and communities by sharing culturally and socially relevant stories through innovative programming, workshops, and initiatives. Their mission is to empower local Seattle-area Latinx artists to create, produce, and promote professional theater in English, Spanish, bilingual, and Spanglish. They are regular participants in Represent!, a Multicultural Playwrights Festival and the Latinx Theatre Commons (LTC).

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Producer/Creator, Service(s) for Artists

text.headline: Intiman Theatre
text.text:
Founded in 1972 by Meg Booker, Intiman Theatre was the first regional theater to present Tony Kushner's Angels in America (1994) and was the recipient of a Tony Award for Outstanding Regional Theatre, (2006) before entering a hiatus and reorganization in 2011. Intiman Theatre formed a partnership with Seattle Central College in 2020 and moved to a new location on the Capitol Hill campus in 2021.

text.headline: Neptune Theatre leased by Seattle Theater Group
text.text:
The Neptune Theatre opened in 1921 in Seattle's University District. Many lessees have managed the ornate nautically-themed facility over the last century. Seattle Theater Group became the lessee of the theater in 2011, undertaking significant renovation of the space from a single-screen movie house to a performing arts facility, retaining its historic character. STG has presented a range of music, cinema, lectures and community-based programming at the Neptune.

text.headline: Thompson's Point of View
text.text:
Thompson's Point of View was a Central District restaurant known for its Northern Louisiana Soul Food, but more so for its role as a neighborhood gathering place. Proprietor and community leader Carl Thompson, Jr. opened the business in 1986. It served as a cultural hub and venue for live Funk, Hip Hop, Soul, and R&B until its closure in 2011, a year after Carl Jr. passed away suddenly at the age of 51.

text.headline: Langston Hughes Performing Arts Institute

Langston Hughes Cultural Arts Center (LHCAC) opened in 1973 in the former Bikur Cholim Synagogue with the support of the Model Cities Program, providing numerous cultural and community services under Seattle Parks and Recreation Department, transitioning to the Langston Hughes Performing Arts Center (LHPAC) in 2001, and the Langston Hughes Performing Arts Institute (LHPAI) under the Seattle Office of Arts and Culture in 2013.

text.headline: Kelly Ethnic Cultural Center & Theatre
text.text:
The Ethnic Cultural Center & Theatre (ECC) at the University of Washington opened its doors in 1972 as a performance venue with the goal of supporting greater diversity in programming within the institution. A direct response to student demands, the ECC has worked with BIPOC students and faculty, as well as community organizations for more than 40 years to encourage cross-cultural exchange and learning. The ECC also housed the Group Theatre Company from 1978 to 1992, when the company moved to the Center House Theatre. In 2013, the ECC was renovated and renamed the Samuel E. Kelly Ethnic Cultural Center in honor of the late leader of minority affairs at the UW. Today it is recognized as the largest and longest standing cultural center on a college campus within the United States.

  • Primary Form of Entity: University Program & Facility
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts

text.headline: Jackson Street Jazz Walk
text.text:
Jackson Street Jazz Walk is an annual event held at various locations in Seattle's Central District. Launched in April 2013 by community organizer Knox Gardner, it harkens back to the days of the early/mid twentieth century, when jazz clubs flourished in the neighborhood and were frequently photographed by Albert J. Smith Jr., whose archives are now in the possession of the Museum of History and Industry.

text.headline: Massive Monkees/The Beacon
text.text:
Massive Monkees is a Seattle based breakdance and hip hop crew that began creating hip hop shows for theater in the late 1990's. The crew consists of dancers, graffiti artists, DJs and general support members who are mostly from Seattle's South End. Massive Monkees creates full length theater production, participates in battle style dance competitions, and has performed with major musical acts such as Macklemore, Jay-Z, Missy Elliott, Public Enemy and more, and were featured on America's Best Dance Crew. Massive Monkees opened their studio The Beacon as a part of Shunpike's Storefronts Seattle in 2013. The Beacon provided art-based programs for the neighborhood and surrounding community in the International District to encourage creative expression and positive change. The Beacon lost its location in November 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and as of 2021 Massive Monkees are still seeking a new studio location.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit, For Profit Business
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Dance, Music, Theatre

text.headline: 12th Avenue Arts
text.text:
12th Avenue Arts opened to the public in 2014 as part of Capitol Hill Housing (Community Roots Housing as of 2020) and based on extensive public/private planning. Two flexible theatres serve a variety of artistic entities within a multi-use facility that includes 88 affordable apartments, as well as restaurants, bars and offices.

text.headline: Al Smith Photographic Archives at MOHAI
text.text:
Al Smith (1916-2008) is widely considered Seattle's preeminent African American photographer. He gained national acclaim in the late 1940s. In the 1960s he attended and photographed civil rights marches and demonstrations, Black Panther rallies, and the appearance of Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) chairperson Stokely Carmichael at Garfield High. He was the unofficial photographer of the 1979 NBA-champion Seattle Supersonics. In 2014 his photographic archive, which covers some 60 years of the daily lives of Seattle's black community in the twentieth century, was donated by the Al Smith Foundation to the Museum of History and Industry (MOHAI). In 2017-2018, the archive was the subject of a major MOHAI exhibition entitled Seattle on the Spot: The Photographs of Al Smith.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Other

text.headline: KEXP-FM
text.text:
Started operations as KCMU in 1972 as a small rock station staffed by students on the University of Washington campus. It was transformed in 2001, in partnership with Paul Allen's Experience Music Project, into KEXP, and moved to an expanded home at Seattle Center in 2015.

text.headline: Rainier Arts Center
text.text:
The Rainier Valley Cultural Center was purchased by South East Effective Development (SEED) in 1995 as a multicultural community performance space and opened its doors in 1997. The 1921 former church space provides performance opportunities, workshops, and summer camps for local youth, and the Center produces an annual Summer Series of outdoor movies, concerts, and plays in Columbia Park. The focus is on serving the ethnically diverse Rainier Valley community. In 2015 the name was changed to the Rainier Arts Center.

text.headline: Center on Contemporary Art (CoCA)
text.text:
Founded in 1980 by a group of artists, art patrons, and arts activists, CoCA' s noted inaugural 1982 exhibition was James Turrell's "Four Light Installations" at the Lippy Building in Pioneer Square. Originally existing without a permanent space, CoCA has presented the work of over 3,000 established and emerging artists in numerous locations in Seattle. CoCA was sponsored by and/or until 1984, when it became an independent non-profit organization.CoCA relocated in 2016 to the Tashiro Kaplan Building.

text.headline: Washington Hall
text.text:
Historic Seattle, with the help of 4Culture, purchased Washington Hall in the Central District in 2009 and restored it as a home for community arts, heritage, and cultural organizations, with a rental program focused on performance and community events. Built in 1908 by a Danish brotherhood, the building was sold in 1973 to Sons of Haiti, an African-American Masonic lodge. Washington Hall has hosted speakers including W.E.B. Du Bois, Marcus Garvey, and Martin Luther King, Jr. as well as numerous performers including Ella Fitzgerald, Jimi Hendrix, and David Byrne, and was the home of On the Boards for 20 years. It reopened to the community in June 2016.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit

text.headline: Seattle Asian Art Museum
text.text:
The Seattle Art Museum (SAM) opened in Volunteer Park in 1933 under founder Dr. Richard E. Fuller. The museum presented modern art and changing exhibitions at the Seattle Art Museum Pavilion at the Seattle Center from 1963 until the museum's move to its present downtown location in Seattle in 1991. A landmark exhibition, Treasures of Tutankhamun, at Seattle Center in 1978 helped to fuel plans for the expansion of the museum to downtown. The Volunteer Park facility was rededicated as the Seattle Asian Art Museum (SAAM) in 1994 focusing on the museum's extensive Asian collections, and underwent a renovation and expansion in 2020. In 2007 a substantial expansion doubled space at the downtown facility, and the museum's Olympic Sculpture Park opened on Seattle's waterfront. SAM's three facilities are home to nearly 25,000 pieces of art from a range of time periods and global cultures.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Presenter

text.headline: City Arts
text.text:
City Arts produces a monthly print magazine as well as online content and events focused on the arts and culture of the Seattle area, reporting on a range of creative disciplines and genres. Founded in Tacoma in 2006, City Arts began as a product of Encore Media Group, the Northwest-based custom publishing company producing Encore Arts Programs for major performing arts organizations. In 2018 City Arts ceased operating due to a lack of funding.

text.headline: Byrd Barr Place
text.text:
Central Area Motivation Program (CAMP) was founded in 1964 as part of the first generation of community-inspired organizations funded by the Economic Opportunity Act. CAMP was centered on supporting the Black communities of Seattle and flourished during the civil rights movement with programming that centered around the creative arts and community beautification. CAMP coupled these with practical assistance such as childcare facilities, and job placement to assist residents in finding a better quality of life. CAMP was also the original home to Black/Arts West, Seattle's first Black theater. Over the years, CAMP has expanded its range of programming into equity-focused services such as energy assistance, a food bank, housing assistance, and education in personal finance. In 2018, CAMP changed its name to Byrd Barr Place in honor of local civil rights leader Roberta Byrd Barr.

  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Multidisciplinary Arts, Interdisciplinary Arts

text.headline: Gallery Onyx/Onyx Fine Arts Collective
text.text:
In operation since 2005, Onyx Fine Arts Collective and its volunteer-run Gallery Onyx are committed to celebrating and promoting the visual artwork of Pacific Northwest artists of African descent. Gallery Onyx moved from Belltown to Pacific Place in 2018 and features rotating exhibits that are representative of the African diaspora, especially in Seattle.

text.headline: Nordic Heritage Museum/National Nordic Museum
text.text:
The Nordic Heritage Museum opened in 1980 in the Ballard neighborhood in the former Webster School, which was rented from Seattle Public Schools. The Nordic Heritage Museum is dedicated to preserving and sharing Nordic and Nordic American culture and does so through folk arts programs, educational programs and exhibitions. In 1993, it was recognized as the only Nordic museum in North America. The lack of a proper climate control system and other building limitations caused the Nordic Heritage Museum to seek a new location. Starting in 2003 the museum began to raise funds and acquire land in Ballard, retaining its connection to this neighborhood founded by Nordic immigrants. After a long fundraising and building process, the new National Nordic Museum opened on May 5, 2018.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Crafts, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Arts Education: Children and Youth, Arts Education: Adults

text.headline: Total Experience Gospel Choir
text.text:
Seattle's longest lasting and most prominent community gospel choir, Total Experience was founded in 1973 by Pastor Patrinell Staten Wright. It was originally established for African American children and teens after a comparable program at Franklin High School was defunded. Adults began participating in the 1990s, and as the ethnic makeup of the Central District changed, so did the choir. They performed in 28 states and 22 countries over the course of 45 years, before their last performance in October 2018. In 2019, the inspirational story of Reverend Wright and Total Experience was immortalized in the film Patrinell: The Total Experience.

  • Primary Form of Entity: For Profit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Music
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Producer/Creator

text.headline: Seattle Fringe Festival
text.text:
The first successful Seattle Fringe Festival took place in 1991, after the establishment of the League of Fringe Theaters in 1989. The event continued off and on for two decades, changing formats, programming, and leadership several times and producing many festivals and collaborations. It has influenced festivals, film, theater, and other events ever since. During their time, SFF hosted an eclectic mix of local and national artists and companies, as well as acts from around the world. The festival most recently ceased operations in 2018, with future plans to be determined.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Festival/Event

text.headline: Wa Na Wari
text.text:
Housed inside a fifth-generation, Black-owned home in the Central District, Wa Na Wari is a community art project centered on making and preserving Black cultural space and the importance of Black land ownership in gentrified communities. Wa Na Wari centers Black creativity through programming within the home, including free art exhibits, film screenings, performances, and workshops. The organization also organizes for Black-led, arts-based solutions to displacement and economic vulnerability. Wa Na Wari was opened in 2019 by four artists-Inye Wokoma, Elisheba Johnson, Rachel Kessler, and Jill Freidberg-and works to create space for Black ownership, possibility and belonging through art, historic preservation, and connection.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Visual Arts, Media Arts, Dance, Folk/Traditional/Heritage Arts, Multidisciplinary Arts
  • Primary Areas of Activity: Arts in Social Service/Social Justice, Arts in Community Development, Presenter/Distributor, Venue/Facility

text.headline: Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture
text.text:
The roots of the Burke Museum date back to 1885, when the Young Naturalists' Society raised money to start a museum to house their growing natural history collection. Soon after, it moved to the campus of the University of Washington and in 1899 was designated as the Washington State Museum. It was named after Judge Thomas Burke in recognition of a bequest in 1962. Over time, the museum continued to grow its programs and collection of fossils, specimens, art and artifacts from the Pacific Northwest and around the Pacific Rim, necessitating a larger facility. Construction on the “New Burke” began in 2016 and was largely guided by the leadership of long time Executive Director, Julie Stein. The New Burke opened to the public in October of 2019.

  • Primary Form of Entity: Nonprofit

text.headline: Re-bar
text.text:
Re-bar opened in 1990 by co-founders Steve Wells and Patrick “Pit” Kweicinski. Their aim was to create a welcoming place for people of all sexualities, genders, and artistic tastes. During their 30 years in operation, a reputation was earned for hosting a wide range of musical experiences, including new artists and widely attended dance nights. Re-bar has been considered one of the last holdouts of Seattle's indie theatre/nightclubs, critical to the city's LGBT and arts scenes. They closed in 2020 with the intent to reopen in South Seattle sometime in the future.

  • Primary Form of Entity: For Profit
  • Primary Artistic Discipline: Theatre, Dance, Music, Cabaret
